Wallaby 23.0.0 prelude section

Mostly based on cycle highlights.

Change-Id: I77d984f39e7c5473f54b7d6fe57c52187f894919
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/72/782172/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- prelude: | The 22.0.0 release includes many new features and bug fixes. Please be sure to read the upgrade section which describes the required actions to upgrade your cloud from 21.0.0 (Ussuri) to 22.0.0 (Wallaby). There are a few major changes worth mentioning. This is not an exhaustive list: - The latest Compute API microversion supported for Wallaby is v2.88. Details on REST API microversions added since the 20.0.0 Train release can be found in the `REST API Version History`__ page. .. __: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html - `Support for accelerators`__ in Nova servers has been improved. Now shelving and unshelving instances using Cyborg accelerators is supported. .. __: https://docs.openstack.org/api-guide/compute/accelerator-support.html - Attaching `neutron ports with QoS minimum bandwidth rules`__ to existing instances is now possible. .. __: https://docs.openstack.org/api-guide/compute/port_with_resource_request.html - The nova-scheduler service now verifies which compute nodes could be used for instances having `requested networks or ports`__ by looking at the network segments related to the compute nodes. .. __: https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-routed-networks.html - The Hyper-V virt driver can now attach Cinder RBD volumes. - The libvirt virt driver now supports new features : - you can `change the default machine type`__ on a compute node safely .. __: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/hw-machine-type.html - you can enable `UEFI secure boot`__ for new instances .. __: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/wallaby/approved/allow-secure-boot-for-qemu-kvm-guests.html - `vDPA (vHost data path acceleration)`__ usage is now possible .. __:https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/wallaby/approved/libvirt-vdpa-support.html

commit_message:
Set 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options in the 'libvirt' plugin to be defined in conf.d/libvirt.yaml

The 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options are currently set by oslo configuration library.
However, in 'monasca_agent/collector/virt/libvirt/inspector.py' file these options cannot be
provided by a configuration file. Changing this to retrieve both options from
'conf.d/libvirt.yaml' file.

Change-Id: I1918fda471e951f42db0d302e371108b664e936c
(cherry picked from commit 085f64578f40152273138898a0dc4566d327dc8f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/58/782958/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osimport monasca_agent.common.config as configuration import monasca_agent.common.util as util# Relevant configuration options must be set in 'conf.d/libvirt.yaml' # file under 'init_config'. # eg. # init_config: # libvirt_type: kvm # libvirt_uri: qemu:///system # # 'libvirt_type' valid choices: ('kvm', 'lxc', 'qemu', 'uml', 'xen') # 'libvirt_uri' is dependent on 'libvirt_type' paths = util.Paths() conf_path = os.path.join(paths.get_confd_path(), 'libvirt.yaml') config = configuration.Config() if os.path.exists(conf_path): try: check_config = config.check_yaml(conf_path) except Exception as e: log.exception('Unable to parse yaml config in {}\n{}' .format(conf_path, str(e))) else: log.debug('No conf.d/libvirt.yaml found for virt/libvirt/inspector.py') init_config = check_config.get('init_config', {}) if init_config is None: init_config = {} return init_config.get('libvirt_uri') or \ self.per_type_uris.get(init_config.get('libvirt_type'), 'qemu:///system')
deleted_lines: from oslo_config import cfgOPTS = [ cfg.StrOpt('libvirt_type', default='kvm', choices=['kvm', 'lxc', 'qemu', 'uml', 'xen'], help='Libvirt domain type.'), cfg.StrOpt('libvirt_uri', default='', help='Override the default libvirt URI ' '(which is dependent on libvirt_type).'), ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(OPTS) return CONF.libvirt_uri or self.per_type_uris.get(CONF.libvirt_type, 'qemu:///system')

commit_message:
Optimize bluestore deployment in kolla-ansible

Adjust the naming of osd related disk variables and optimize the
deployment of bluestore.

Update bluestore usage documentation.

Depends-On: Ic2cd282eb81368b7361a8012544e0b240102e3f5

Change-Id: I602f1b48f8390a04e340368280ece6e6d1317474
Closes-bug: #1776888

commit_message:
Ensure keystone kolla_dev_repos_directory accessable

Ensure keystone kolla_dev_repos_directory accessable, or it will
be failed when keystone container start.

commit_message:
Support nova dev mode in kolla

Add a possibility to mount sources as volumes to containers,
in "more than documentation" way.

Change-Id: I229b0bc02ec101e03c3de63e3a5347f8721192b3

commit_message:
docs: Remove duplicated PCI passthrough extra spec info

There's also a PCI passthrough guide. Use that instead, allowing us to
remove the sections for various extra specs from the 'user/flavors'
guide:

- hw:pci_numa_affinity_policy
- pci_passthrough:alias

Change-Id: I5701d284c2cfdadf825f8e2f699651b3f8c0c9ab
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
docs: Remove duplicate TPM extra spec info

We have a perfectly good TPM guide. Enhance that, allowing us to remove
the special section dedicated to this from the generic flavor docs.

Change-Id: If484074c01595f747f9201b5ec12164779195b61
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/35/781435/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: .. _vtpm-flavor: Emulated Virtual TPM If supported by the compute host, you can add an :doc:`emulated trusted platform module (TPM) </admin/emulated-tpm>` to the guest OS. .. code:: console $ openstack flavor set FLAVOR-NAME \ --property hw:tpm_version=$VERSION \ --property hw:tpm_model=$MODEL ``hw:tpm_version`` is required to enable support. Valid ``$VERSION`` values are: - ``1.2`` : Selects TPM version 1.2 support. - ``2.0`` : Selects TPM version 2.0 support. ``hw:tpm_model`` is optional. Valid ``$MODEL`` values are: - ``tpm-tis``: Selects TIS device model. This is the default value. - ``tpm-crb``: Selects CRB device model. Only valid for TPM version 2.0.

commit_message:
Support serial mode to upgrade ceph

When the kolla version changes, such as adding new features or ceph
version upgrades, users need to upgrade the old version of the image
to the new version.
This commit provides a safer way to upgrade, serial mode, it has the
following features:

1. Only upgrade one ceph component on one node at a time.
2. Perform ceph status detection before upgrading each component,
upgrade only in HEALTH_OK state.
3.When upgrading osd, noout and norebalance are set before the upgrade
to prevent data rebalancing. The osd upgrade on the same node is also
run in sequence.

Please refer to the "Deploy ceph individually and upgrade securely"
section in the kolla-ansible documentation[0].

[0] kolla-ansible/doc/source/reference/ceph-guide.rst

Change-Id: Ia4cd15d64aef8d05d33b8a76c8d951d424dfe069
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/41/582441/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Deploy ceph individually and upgrade securely ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ In this section, it will show how to install ceph individually and perform a secure image upgrade. For a simple example, if need to install ceph, horizon, keystone and cinder. It is recommended to install ceph first, then install other openstack components. The configuration path and file are as follows: .. code-block:: ini [root@deploy-node deploy-sample]# tree -L 4 .  kolla-deploy  config-test  custom   ceph.conf   cinder.conf   keystone.conf  globals.yml  kolla-build.conf  multinode-inventory  passwords.yml .. end Build ceph image ---------------- First, build the ceph images independently, the kolla-build.conf can be configured as follows: .. code-block:: yaml [DEFAULT] base = centos profile = image_ceph registry = "docker_registry_address" username = password = namespace = kolla install_type = source [profiles] image_openstack = cron,kolla-toolbox,fluentd,horizon,keystone,memcached,rabbitmq,cinder image_ceph = cron,kolla-toolbox,fluentd,ceph .. end Then run the following command to build the ceph image: .. code-block:: console kolla-build --config-file config-test/kolla-build.conf --push --tag ceph-4.0.2.0001 .. end Configuration ------------- Prepare the disk reference example above. Configure the multinode-inventory file as follows: .. code-block:: ini [storage-mon] ceph-node-1 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth0 api_interface=eth0 storage_interface=eth0 cluster_interface=eth0 ceph-node-2 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth1 api_interface=eth1 storage_interface=eth1 cluster_interface=eth1 ceph-node-3 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth0 api_interface=eth0 storage_interface=eth0 cluster_interface=eth0 [storage-osd] ceph-node-1 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth0 api_interface=eth0 storage_interface=eth0 cluster_interface=eth0 ceph-node-2 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth1 api_interface=eth1 storage_interface=eth1 cluster_interface=eth1 ceph-node-3 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth0 api_interface=eth0 storage_interface=eth0 cluster_interface=eth0 [storage-rgw] ceph-node-1 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth0 api_interface=eth0 storage_interface=eth0 cluster_interface=eth0 [storage-mgr] ceph-node-1 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth0 api_interface=eth0 storage_interface=eth0 cluster_interface=eth0 ceph-node-2 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth1 api_interface=eth1 storage_interface=eth1 cluster_interface=eth1 [storage-mds] ceph-node-1 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth0 api_interface=eth0 storage_interface=eth0 cluster_interface=eth0 ceph-node-2 ansible_user=userA network_interface=eth1 api_interface=eth1 storage_interface=eth1 cluster_interface=eth1 [storage-nfs] [ceph-mon:children] storage-mon [ceph-rgw:children] storage-rgw [ceph-osd:children] storage-osd [ceph-mgr:children] storage-mgr [ceph-mds:children] storage-mds [ceph-nfs:children] storage-nfs .. end .. note:: If the NIC name is different between ceph hosts, please configure the NIC name as above. .. end Configure the globals.yml file as follows: .. code-block:: yaml node_custom_config: "{{ CONFIG_DIR }}/custom" kolla_install_type: "source" kolla_internal_vip_address: "your_vip_address" docker_registry: "docker_registry_address" docker_namespace: "kolla" enable_keystone: "yes" enable_horizon: "yes" enable_ceph: "yes" enable_cinder: "yes" enable_ceph_rgw: "yes" enable_ceph_mds: "yes" osd_initial_weight: "auto" .. end Deploy ceph individually ------------------------ Run the following command to pull ceph images .. code-block:: console kolla-ansible pull --configdir config-test/ -i config-test/multinode-inventory --passwords config-test/passwords.yml --tags ceph -e openstack_release=ceph-4.0.2.0001 .. end Run the following command to deploy ceph .. code-block:: console kolla-ansible deploy --configdir config-test/ -i config-test/multinode-inventory --passwords config-test/passwords.yml --tags ceph -e openstack_release=ceph-4.0.2.0001 .. end Upgrade ceph image securely --------------------------- When the version of the kolla changes, such as some new feature additions or ceph version upgrades, users need to update the ceph cluster from the old image to the new image, which provides a secure upgrade method "one-by-one". In the ocata and pike version, the ceph version used by the kolla is jewel, and in the queens version, it was upgraded to luminous. To upgrade from jewel to luminous, it need to upgrade the mon component before upgrading other components. So the "one-by-one" upgrade is divided into two phases. The first phase upgrades all mon containers in turn. For example, there are three mon nodes, so the upgrade process is: .. code-block:: console Start-->ceph-node-1-->check status-->HEALTH_OK-->upgrade mon.1-->next node ceph-node-2-->check status-->HEALTH_OK-->upgrade mon.2-->next node ceph-node-3-->check status-->HEALTH_OK-->upgrade mon.3-->End .. end In the second phase, other components are upgraded in turn, the mgr, mds, rgw and nfs upgrade process is similar to mon, as follows: .. code-block:: console mgr/rgw/mds/nfs upgrade process: check status-->HEALTH_OK-->upgrade mgr/rgw/mds/nfs .. end The osd upgrade process requires two additional commands to prevent data migration, as follows: .. code-block:: console osd upgrade process: check status-->HEALTH_OK-->run "ceph osd set noout && ceph osd set norebalance"-->upgrade one osd -->run "ceph osd unset noout && ceph osd unset norebalance" .. end For example, there are two nodes, each with mgr, rgw, mds, nfs and two osd. Then the upgrade process is as follows: .. code-block:: console Start-->ceph-node-1-->mgr upgrade process-->osd.1 upgrade process-->osd.2 upgrade process-->rgw upgrade process-->mds upgrade process-->nfs upgrade process-->next node ceph-node-2-->mgr upgrade process-->osd.3 upgrade process-->osd.4 upgrade process-->rgw upgrade process-->mds upgrade process-->nfs upgrade process-->End .. end Configuration ------------- Configure the following parameters in globals.yml: .. code-block:: yaml ########################## ## Ceph_upgrade_one_by_one ########################## ceph_upgrade_one_by_one: "true" ceph_serial: "{{ '1' if ceph_upgrade_one_by_one | bool else '0' }}" ceph_upgrade_mon_only: "false" ceph_state_change_time: 3 ceph_health_check_retries: 15 ceph_health_check_delay: 20 .. end ``ceph_upgrade_one_by_one`` represents whether to enable the one_by_one upgrade. ``ceph_serial`` represents how many hosts are executed concurrently, ``0`` means no limit. ``ceph_upgrade_mon_only`` represents whether to upgrade the mon component, ``false`` means to upgrade other components. ``ceph_state_change_time`` means that after upgrading a component, it will sleep for some time to wait for the change of ceph state. ``ceph_health_check_retries`` and ``ceph_health_check_delay`` represents the number of attempts and intervals for obtaining ceph health. During this time, if the ceph status doesn't return to "HEALTH_OK", the upgrade will be aborted. Please set the appropriate value according to the actual situation. Upgrade ceph securely --------------------- Please build a new ceph image, for example the tag is "ceph-4.0.2.0002". Then execute the following command to upgrade .. code-block:: console kolla-ansible upgrade --configdir config-test/ -i config-test/multinode-inventory --passwords config-test/passwords.yml --tags ceph -e openstack_release=ceph-4.0.2.0002 .. end Further, if the user wants to manually check after upgrading a node and then upgrade the next node, can use "--limit". .. code-block:: console kolla-ansible upgrade --configdir config-test/ -i config-test/multinode-inventory --passwords config-test/passwords.yml --tags ceph -e openstack_release=ceph-4.0.2.0002 --limit ceph-node-1 .. end

commit_message:
docs: Add a real-time guide

This beefy patch closes a long-standing TODO and allows us to move yet
more information out of the flavors guide and into specific documents.
This, combined with existing documentation in place, means we can remove
the sections for various extra specs from the 'user/flavors' guide:

- hw:cpu_realtime            -> doc/source/admin/real-time.rst
- hw:cpu_realtime_mask       -> doc/source/admin/real-time.rst
- hw:emulator_threads_policy -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_policy              -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_thread_policy       -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_sockets             -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_cores               -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_threads             -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_max_sockets         -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_max_cores           -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:cpu_max_threads         -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:numa_nodes              -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:numa_cpus.N             -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:numa_mem.N              -> doc/source/admin/cpu-topologies.rst
- hw:mem_page_size           -> doc/source/admin/huge-pages.rst

Multiple improvements to the libvirt extra spec docs are included here,
for want of a better place to include them.

Change-Id: I02b044f8246f4a42481bb5f00259842692b29b71
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/34/781434/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _numa-topologies: memory bandwidth. To configure guest NUMA nodes, you can use the :nova:extra-spec:`hw:numa_nodes` flavor extra spec. For example, to restrict an instance's vCPUs to a single host NUMA node, $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR --property hw:numa_nodes=1 $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR --property hw:numa_nodes=2 The allocation of instance vCPUs and memory from different host NUMA nodes cancan be important for some workloads. You can configure the allocation of instance vCPUs and memory across each **guest** NUMA node using the :nova:extra-spec:`hw:numa_cpus.{num}` and :nova:extra-spec:`hw:numa_mem.{num}` extra specs respectively. For example, to spread the 6 vCPUs and 6 GB of memory $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR --property hw:numa_nodes=2 $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ The ``{num}`` parameter is an index of *guest* NUMA nodes and may not correspond to *host* NUMA nodes. For example, on a platform with two NUMA nodes, the scheduler may opt to place guest NUMA node 0, as referenced in ``hw:numa_mem.0`` on host NUMA node 1 and vice versa. Similarly, the CPUs bitmask specified in the value for ``hw:numa_cpus.{num}`` refer to *guest* vCPUs and may not correspond to *host* CPUs. As such, this feature cannot be used to constrain instances to specific host CPUs or NUMA nodes. .. warning:: If the combined values of ``hw:numa_cpus.{num}`` or ``hw:numa_mem.{num}`` are greater than the available number of CPUs or memory respectively, an exception will be raised. .. note:: and ``hw:num_mem.N``, refer to :doc:`/configuration/extra-specs`. .. _cpu-pinning-policies:pinned or not. They can be configured using the :nova:extra-spec:`hw:cpu_policy` extra spec and equivalent image metadata property. There are three policies: ``dedicated``, ``mixed`` and $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR --property hw:cpu_policy=dedicated $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR --property resources:PCPU=N (where ``N`` is the number of vCPUs defined in the flavor). $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR --property hw:cpu_policy=shared:nova:extra-spec:`hw:cpu_dedicated_mask` or, if :doc:`real-time <real-time>` is enabled, in the :nova:extra-spec:`hw:cpu_realtime_mask` extra spec. Fortotal and the first 2 vCPUs as pinned CPUs, run: $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \To configure a flavor to use the ``mixed`` CPU policy with 4 vCPUs in total and the first 2 vCPUs as pinned **real-time** CPUs, run: $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ refer to :doc:`/configuration/extra-specs` .. note:: For more information about real-time functionality, refer to the :doc:`documentation <real-time>`. $ openstack image set $IMAGE --property hw_cpu_policy=dedicated $ openstack image set $IMAGE --property hw_cpu_policy=shared $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ :doc:`/configuration/extra-specs`. $ openstack image set $IMAGE \ $ openstack image set $IMAGE \ $ openstack image set $IMAGE \.. _emulator-thread-pinning-policies: $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \:oslo.config:option:`compute.cpu_shared_set` if configured, else across all pCPUs of the instance. To configure a flavor to use the ``share`` emulator thread policy, run: $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \The above behavior can be summarized in this helpful table: .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 :stub-columns: 1 * - - :oslo.config:option:`compute.cpu_shared_set` set - :oslo.config:option:`compute.cpu_shared_set` unset * - ``hw:emulator_treads_policy`` unset (default) - Pinned to all of the instance's pCPUs - Pinned to all of the instance's pCPUs * - ``hw:emulator_threads_policy`` = ``share`` - Pinned to :oslo.config:option:`compute.cpu_shared_set` - Pinned to all of the instance's pCPUs * - ``hw:emulator_threads_policy`` = ``isolate`` - Pinned to a single pCPU distinct from the instance's pCPUs - Pinned to a single pCPU distinct from the instance's pCPUs refer to :nova:extra-spec:`the documentation <hw:emulator_threads_policy>`.sockets. To configure a flavor to use two sockets, run: $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR --property hw:cpu_sockets=2 $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \and ``hw:cpu_threads``, refer to :doc:`/configuration/extra-specs`.exceeded. For example, to ensure no more than two sockets, eight cores and one thread are defined in the instance topology, run: $ openstack flavor set $FLAVOR \ --property hw:cpu_max_sockets=2 \ --property hw:cpu_max_cores=8 \ --property hw:cpu_max_threads=1``hw:cpu_max_cores``, and ``hw:cpu_max_threads``, refer to :doc:`/configuration/extra-specs`. $ openstack image set $IMAGE \ $ openstack image set $IMAGE \
deleted_lines: memory bandwidth. To restrict an instance's vCPUs to a single host NUMA node, $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] --property hw:numa_nodes=1 $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] --property hw:numa_nodes=2 The allocation of instances vCPUs and memory from different host NUMA nodes cancan be important for some workloads. To spread the 6 vCPUs and 6 GB of memory $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] --property hw:numa_nodes=2 $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \ $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \and ``hw:num_mem.N``, refer to the :ref:`NUMA topology <extra-specs-numa-topology>` guide.pinned or not. There are three policies: ``dedicated``, ``mixed`` and $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] --property hw:cpu_policy=dedicated $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] --property resources:PCPU=N where ``N`` is the number of vCPUs defined in the flavor. $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] --property hw:cpu_policy=shared``hw:cpu_dedicated_mask`` or, if real-time is enabled (``hw:cpu_realtime``\ = yes), in the ``hw:cpu_realtime_mask`` extra spec. Fortotal and the first 2 vCPUs as pinned CPUs, with the ``hw:cpu_realtime_mask`` extra spec, run: $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \To create the mixed instance with the real-time extra specs, run: $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \ refer to the :doc:`/user/flavors` guide. $ openstack image set [IMAGE_ID] --property hw_cpu_policy=dedicated $ openstack image set [IMAGE_ID] --property hw_cpu_policy=shared $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \ $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \ $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \ $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \ $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \ the :doc:`/user/flavors` guide. $ openstack image set [IMAGE_ID] \ $ openstack image set [IMAGE_ID] \ $ openstack image set [IMAGE_ID] \ $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \:oslo.config:option:`compute.cpu_shared_set`. To configure a flavor to use the ``share`` emulator thread policy, run: $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \ refer to the :doc:`/user/flavors` guide.sockets. To configure a flavor to use a maximum of two sockets, run: $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] --property hw:cpu_sockets=2 $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] \and ``hw:cpu_threads``, refer to the :doc:`/user/flavors` guide.exceeded. For example, to ensure no more than two sockets are defined in the instance topology, run: $ openstack flavor set [FLAVOR_ID] --property hw:cpu_max_sockets=2``hw:cpu_max_cores``, and ``hw:cpu_max_threads``, refer to the :doc:`/user/flavors` guide. $ openstack image set [IMAGE_ID] \ $ openstack image set [IMAGE_ID] \

commit_message:
[WIP] Use kolla-cli in gate jobs

This work is very much in debug and should be ignored for now.
The idea is that deploy, upgrade, etc will be done with the kolla-cli.
It will likely take many iterations to get this to work.

Depends-On: I4dc1e1ce8d1839e7550479799fb00e2613d979df

Change-Id: I6cd898460aa4bbe68d3f86bc7733d58ac74f392f

commit_message:
Fix ceph_mon check ceph cluster network

When deploying ceph_mon node, it will check cluster interface
and if there has no that interface,kolla-ansible will raise an
error, but this is not necessary for ceph itself.

Reslove by generating different configure task depends on different
ceph roles.

Change-Id: I64e5b3ee9136235070661685e72e4c6fa411cda4
Closes-Bug: #1729589
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/88/517288/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: - name: Copying over config.json files for services template: src: "{{ item }}.json.j2" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/{{ item }}/config.json" with_items: - "ceph-mon" - "ceph-osd" - "ceph-rgw"

commit_message:
Use testenv deps instead of repeating the dependencies

The list of dependencies was incomplete in several tox environments.
Instead of replicating it, simply refer to the master testenv dependency
list.

Also use white space indenting consistently to be easier on the
eyes.

Change-Id: I80198d773d9cf9fdae72cfc649b533e1d14bb181

commit_message:
Update virtual media boot-related constants

Constants related to virtual media boot are modified to identify LC and
RAC event messages only, and not the version.

Story: 2008708
Task: 42042

Change-Id: Id8d1584bb07378fc99247ed047a5df2645a7ce72

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Change-Id: I151e1cae71e4fd69db8e995e7464f109041a3990

commit_message:
Update RETRY_COUNT for virtual media boot

Increase RETRY_COUNT to 35 to provide sufficient time to complete
already running iDRAC configuration job. This has been observed when
ironic performs boot mode synchronization, because the node boot mode
is not the same as bare-metal boot mode.

Story: 2008709
Task: 42043

Change-Id: I78c503a65c0c3fdb17773279d87db425926fa275
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy-oem-idrac refs/changes/42/780242/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: RETRY_COUNT = 35

commit_message:
Base unit test framework to test new API policy enforcement

It is just base framework which will help adding tests for various
API policy rules.

Partially-Implements blueprint: secure-rbac-roles

Change-Id: Ic4ae2f70fabf21e489da7149ea005e873563380b

implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from neutron_lib import context from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_utils import uuidutils from neutron.tests import base as tests_base class PolicyBase(tests_base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): # NOTE(slaweq): Enforcing new policies has to be done before calling # super() as in BaseTestCase policies are initialized and config # options has to be set properly at that point already. # That tests are testing only new default policies. cfg.CONF.set_override( 'enforce_new_defaults', True, group='oslo_policy') cfg.CONF.set_override( 'enforce_scope', True, group='oslo_policy') super(PolicyBase, self).setUp() self.project_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self.system_user_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self.user_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self._prepare_system_scope_personas() self._prepare_project_scope_personas() def _prepare_system_scope_personas(self): self.system_admin_ctx = context.Context( user=self.system_user_id, roles=['admin', 'member', 'reader'], system_scope='all') self.system_member_ctx = context.Context( user=self.system_user_id, roles=['member', 'reader'], system_scope='all') self.system_reader_ctx = context.Context( user=self.system_user_id, roles=['reader'], system_scope='all') def _prepare_project_scope_personas(self): self.project_admin_ctx = context.Context( user=self.user_id, roles=['admin', 'member', 'reader'], project_id=self.project_id) self.project_member_ctx = context.Context( user=self.user_id, roles=['member', 'reader'], project_id=self.project_id) self.project_reader_ctx = context.Context( user=self.user_id, roles=['reader'], project_id=self.project_id)

subject: Fix invalid JSON generated by quota details
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-03-19 15:11:10.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/objects/quota.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/41b09945597380266cc4ff56958aa4143a6d6d98', 'message': "Fix invalid JSON generated by quota details

The value fetched by Quotasv2_detail.get_resources() is ultimately
returned by Reservation.get_total_reservations_map. The total_reserved
value is returned by a sqlalchemy sum(), and is of a type defined by
the database driver in use. PyMySQL returns a Decimal here, which
the api layer serialises to JSON as a string.

Note that if a resource has no reservations then its value will be
defaulted in DbQuotaDriver.get_detailed_tenant_quotas to the integer
value 0. This means that the value is an integer if zero, or a string
otherwise. This causes parsing difficulties for client libraries which
do strict type checking.

Testing note:
This method is already covered by the unit test
TestQuotaDbApi.test_get_reservations_for_resource, which also already
tests the return value and, implicitly, its type. However, it does not
currently fail because the unit tests run with SQLite rather than MySQL.
SQLite returns an int where MySQL returns a Decimal, which does not
trigger the bug.

TestQuotaDbApi.test_get_reservations_for_resource is sufficient to
demonstrate that the patch doesn't regress SQLite. We were not able to
think of a deterministic way to write a Tempest test for this, which
would cover MySQL. Ideally we would have the ability to run the DB test
suites under MySQL and PostreSQL in addition to SQLite using oslo.db's
OpportunisticDbFixture, but the scope of that is larger than this
change.

Closes-Bug: #1918565
Change-Id: Icda0d63f2f5ea72bde423296c76aa46646fa98a8
(cherry picked from commit 9ed17cec2d4ce0bd27e37c2877a413f5b302f4cd)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix invalid JSON generated by quota details

The value fetched by Quotasv2_detail.get_resources() is ultimately
returned by Reservation.get_total_reservations_map. The total_reserved
value is returned by a sqlalchemy sum(), and is of a type defined by
the database driver in use. PyMySQL returns a Decimal here, which
the api layer serialises to JSON as a string.

Note that if a resource has no reservations then its value will be
defaulted in DbQuotaDriver.get_detailed_tenant_quotas to the integer
value 0. This means that the value is an integer if zero, or a string
otherwise. This causes parsing difficulties for client libraries which
do strict type checking.

Testing note:
This method is already covered by the unit test
TestQuotaDbApi.test_get_reservations_for_resource, which also already
tests the return value and, implicitly, its type. However, it does not
currently fail because the unit tests run with SQLite rather than MySQL.
SQLite returns an int where MySQL returns a Decimal, which does not
trigger the bug.

TestQuotaDbApi.test_get_reservations_for_resource is sufficient to
demonstrate that the patch doesn't regress SQLite. We were not able to
think of a deterministic way to write a Tempest test for this, which
would cover MySQL. Ideally we would have the ability to run the DB test
suites under MySQL and PostreSQL in addition to SQLite using oslo.db's
OpportunisticDbFixture, but the scope of that is larger than this
change.

Closes-Bug: #1918565
Change-Id: Icda0d63f2f5ea72bde423296c76aa46646fa98a8
(cherry picked from commit 9ed17cec2d4ce0bd27e37c2877a413f5b302f4cd)

commit_message:
test integrate with docker-compose

There are serveral reason to do this.

- operators chould re-create the container very easily. just use
  docker-compose up or down
  
- all the container parameters are saved in the disk. operators could
  know waht is the exact parameters used.
  
- This also simplified the ansible logical.

Change-Id: I1f09b6702b26175011bf53acbcbae29c510889f5

commit_message:
Implement Almanach ansible role

Almanach record the utilization of OpenStack resources for each tenant.
Add ansible role to deploy Almanach.

Implements: blueprint almanach-ansible-role
Change-Id: I214885354a2bbf4629fc534e92019f69069d711d
Depends-On: Iba2e16772864a6f0169ec43d7a87d741882cd51c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/44/498944/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- - name: Restart almanach-api container vars: service_name: "almanach-api" service: "{{ almanach_services[service_name] }}" config_json: "{{ almanach_config_jsons.results|selectattr('item.key', 'equalto', service_name)|first }}" almanach_conf: "{{ almanach_confs.results|selectattr('item.key', 'equalto', service_name)|first }}" policy_json: "{{ almanach_policy_jsons.results|selectattr('item.key', 'equalto', service_name)|first }}" almanach_api_container: "{{ check_almanach_containers.results|selectattr('item.key', 'equalto', service_name)|first }}" kolla_docker: action: "recreate_or_restart_container" common_options: "{{ docker_common_options }}" name: "{{ service.container_name }}" image: "{{ service.image }}" volumes: "{{ service.volumes }}" when: - action != "config" - inventory_hostname in groups[service.group] - service.enabled | bool - config_json.changed | bool or almanach_conf.changed | bool or policy_json.changed | bool or almanach_api_container.changed | bool - name: Restart almanach-collector container vars: service_name: "almanach-collector" service: "{{ almanach_services[service_name] }}" config_json: "{{ almanach_config_jsons.results|selectattr('item.key', 'equalto', service_name)|first }}" almanach_conf: "{{ almanach_confs.results|selectattr('item.key', 'equalto', service_name)|first }}" policy_json: "{{ almanach_policy_jsons.results|selectattr('item.key', 'equalto', service_name)|first }}" almanach_collector_container: "{{ check_almanach_containers.results|selectattr('item.key', 'equalto', service_name)|first }}" kolla_docker: action: "recreate_or_restart_container" common_options: "{{ docker_common_options }}" name: "{{ service.container_name }}" image: "{{ service.image }}" volumes: "{{ service.volumes }}" when: - commit_message:
Update Bifrost playbooks

Change-Id: I647971ed480aa097a62db90ef7e31af7fce8bfd2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/35/425435/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Add bifrost_deploy container to inventory add_host: name: "bifrost_deploy" ansible_connection: docker changed_when: false - name: Creating directories for installing ssh keys delegate_to: "bifrost_deploy" file: path: "{{item}}" state: directory mode: 0755 with_items: - /root/.ssh - /home/ironic/.ssh delegate_to: "bifrost_deploy" command: "{{item}}" with_items: - cp -f /etc/bifrost/id_rsa /root/.ssh/id_rsa - cp -f /etc/bifrost/id_rsa.pub /root/.ssh/id_rsa.pub - cp -f /etc/bifrost/ssh_config /root/.ssh/config - cp -f /etc/bifrost/id_rsa /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa - cp -f /etc/bifrost/id_rsa.pub /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa.pub - cp -f /etc/bifrost/ssh_config /home/ironic/.ssh/config - chmod 600 /root/.ssh/id_rsa - chmod 600 /root/.ssh/id_rsa.pub - chmod 600 /root/.ssh/config - chmod 600 /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa - chmod 600 /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa.pub - chmod 600 /home/ironic/.ssh/config - chown ironic:ironic /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa - chown ironic:ironic /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa.pub - chown ironic:ironic /home/ironic/.ssh/config - name: Bootstrap bifrost (this may take several minutes) delegate_to: "bifrost_deploy" command: "{{item}}" with_items: - bash ./scripts/env-setup.sh - bash env-vars - cp /etc/bifrost/rabbitmq-env.conf /etc/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-env.conf - ansible-playbook -vvvv -i /bifrost/playbooks/inventory/localhost /bifrost/playbooks/install.yaml -e @/etc/bifrost/bifrost.yml -e @/etc/bifrost/dib.yml -e skip_package_install=true
deleted_lines: - name: Bootstrap bifrost (this may take several minutes) command: > docker exec bifrost_deploy bash -c '/bifrost/scripts/env-setup.sh && source /bifrost/env-vars && cp /etc/bifrost/rabbitmq-env.conf /etc/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-env.conf && ansible-playbook -vvvv -i /bifrost/playbooks/inventory/localhost /bifrost/playbooks/install.yaml -e @/etc/bifrost/bifrost.yml -e @/etc/bifrost/dib.yml -e skip_package_install=true' command: > docker exec bifrost_deploy bash -c 'mkdir /root/.ssh ; mkdir /home/ironic/.ssh; cp -f /etc/bifrost/id_rsa /root/.ssh/id_rsa && cp -f /etc/bifrost/id_rsa.pub /root/.ssh/id_rsa.pub && cp -f /etc/bifrost/ssh_config /root/.ssh/config && cp -f /etc/bifrost/id_rsa /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa && cp -f /etc/bifrost/id_rsa.pub /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa.pub && cp -f /etc/bifrost/ssh_config /home/ironic/.ssh/config && chmod 600 /root/.ssh/id_rsa && chmod 600 /root/.ssh/id_rsa.pub && chmod 600 /root/.ssh/config && chmod 600 /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa && chmod 600 /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa.pub && chmod 600 /home/ironic/.ssh/config && chown ironic:ironic /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa && chown ironic:ironic /home/ironic/.ssh/id_rsa.pub && chown ironic:ironic /home/ironic/.ssh/config'

commit_message:
Fix vagrant dev env build

Remove references to genconfig and kolla-build.yml so the vagrant
environment can be built without error.

Change-Id: I1b55b1fcddb405d380189cd4474685e4e828c095
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/37/466337/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Use local docker registry sed -i -r "s,^[# ]*namespace *=.+$,namespace = ${REGISTRY}/lokolla," /etc/kolla/kolla-build.conf sed -i -r "s,^[# ]*push *=.+$,push = True," /etc/kolla/kolla-build.conf tox -c ${KOLLA_PATH}/tox.ini -e genconfig

commit_message:
[WIP] Added playbooks for snap deployment

Snap is a telemetry-framework that can be used to collect
and publish metrics. This patch adds playbook for its deployment.
This patch also adds template of task manifest from which SNAP tasks are
created.

Change-Id: I32813dd353e96a02c826cfc541a1af4e8d7a91a4
Partially-implements: bp/monitoring
Co-Authored-By: Sayantani Goswami <sayantani.goswami@intel.com>

commit_message:
Init kibana search dashboard visualization

Add elasticsearch ansible module and init kibana

Change-Id: Ifa5db6d20355396f0950c2852b2ec1ade1d258db
Implements: blueprint add-elasticsearch-module
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/71/476071/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: --- - name: Wait for kibana port wait_for: host: "{{ kolla_internal_vip_address }}" port: "{{ kibana_server_port }}" run_once: true connection: local - name: Wait for kibana to register in elasticsearch uri: url: "{{ internal_protocol }}://{{ kolla_internal_vip_address }}:{{ elasticsearch_port }}/.kibana" status_code: 200 register: result until: result.status == 200 retries: 5 delay: 2 run_once: true connection: local - name: Get kibana default indexes uri: HEADER_Content-Type: application/json url: "{{ internal_protocol }}://{{ kolla_internal_vip_address }}:{{ elasticsearch_port }}/.kibana" method: GET register: kibana_default_indexes run_once: true connection: local when: kibana_default_index is defined - name: Set kibana default indexes fact set_fact: kibana_default_indexes: "{{ kibana_default_indexes.json | default([]) }}" when: - kibana_default_indexes is defined run_once: true connection: local - name: Add index pattern to kibana uri: url: "{{ internal_protocol }}://{{ kolla_internal_vip_address }}:{{ elasticsearch_port }}/.kibana/index-pattern/{{ kibana_default_index_pattern }}" method: PUT body: "{{ kibana_default_index | to_json }}" body_format: json status_code: 201 run_once: true connection: local when: - kibana_default_index is defined - kibana_default_indexes is defined - kibana_default_indexes['.kibana']['mappings']['config']['properties']['defaultIndex'] is not defined - name: Find kibana version command: docker exec -t kibana /opt/kibana/bin/kibana --version register: kibana_version run_once: true changed_when: true when: - kibana_default_index is defined - kibana_default_indexes is defined - kibana_default_indexes['.kibana']['mappings']['config']['properties']['defaultIndex'] is not defined - set_fact: kibana_version: "{{ kibana_version.stdout }}" run_once: true connection: local when: - kibana_default_index is defined - kibana_default_indexes is defined - kibana_default_indexes['.kibana']['mappings']['config']['properties']['defaultIndex'] is not defined - name: Change kibana config to set index as defaultIndex uri: url: "http://{{ kolla_internal_vip_address }}:{{ elasticsearch_port }}/.kibana/config/{{ kibana_version }}" method: PUT body: defaultIndex: "{{ kibana_default_index_pattern }}" body_format: json status_code: 200 run_once: true connection: local when: - kibana_default_index is defined - kibana_default_indexes is defined - kibana_default_indexes['.kibana']['mappings']['config']['properties']['defaultIndex'] is not defined

commit_message:
Add Apache License Content in index.rst

1. What is the problem?
Apache License 2.0 is lack in ./releasenotes/source/index.rst

No need

commit_message:
Remove layout overrides and use tripleo-ci templates instead

As part of [1] and in line with all other tripleo repos lets use
the tripleo-ci templates. The files: and irrelevant-files matches
are moved to tripleo-ci in the depends-on. This leaves only the
undercloud-minion job in the overrides as it isn't covered by the
templates, but updates tags.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:tripleo-ci-reduce

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/781322

Change-Id: Id8bdcc314f68fb35050254c6c64fd2317c2555de

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I6a30ef8373ba30cbc9c9d0d6de1d640dc349d967

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie501d9e209309990a0ec4d7a4be6f306277cb2b4

Backend creation should happen on the last host in the group, instead
of the first one, since we put LB in MAINT state during deployment, while

'}]
commit_message:
Fix condition when to create backends

Backend creation should happen on the last host in the group, instead
of the first one, since we put LB in MAINT state during deployment, while
other containers are not ready yet. Thus we should be creating backends
at the very end of the deployment, when all containers are set.

Change-Id: I3d5811e059d1b5cb3e87fe7657872e41105c832e
Closes-Bug: #1920964

commit_message:
Set 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options in the 'libvirt' plugin to be defined in conf.d/libvirt.yaml

The 'libvirt_type' and 'libvirt_uri' options are currently set by oslo configuration library.
However, in 'monasca_agent/collector/virt/libvirt/inspector.py' file these options cannot be
provided by a configuration file. Changing this to retrieve both options from
'conf.d/libvirt.yaml' file.

Change-Id: I1918fda471e951f42db0d302e371108b664e936c
(cherry picked from commit 085f64578f40152273138898a0dc4566d327dc8f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/59/782959/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osimport monasca_agent.common.config as configuration import monasca_agent.common.util as util# Relevant configuration options must be set in 'conf.d/libvirt.yaml' # file under 'init_config'. # eg. # init_config: # libvirt_type: kvm # libvirt_uri: qemu:///system # # 'libvirt_type' valid choices: ('kvm', 'lxc', 'qemu', 'uml', 'xen') # 'libvirt_uri' is dependent on 'libvirt_type' paths = util.Paths() conf_path = os.path.join(paths.get_confd_path(), 'libvirt.yaml') config = configuration.Config() if os.path.exists(conf_path): try: check_config = config.check_yaml(conf_path) except Exception as e: log.exception('Unable to parse yaml config in {}\n{}' .format(conf_path, str(e))) else: log.debug('No conf.d/libvirt.yaml found for virt/libvirt/inspector.py') init_config = check_config.get('init_config', {}) if init_config is None: init_config = {} return init_config.get('libvirt_uri') or \ self.per_type_uris.get(init_config.get('libvirt_type'), 'qemu:///system')
deleted_lines: from oslo_config import cfgOPTS = [ cfg.StrOpt('libvirt_type', default='kvm', choices=['kvm', 'lxc', 'qemu', 'uml', 'xen'], help='Libvirt domain type.'), cfg.StrOpt('libvirt_uri', default='', help='Override the default libvirt URI ' '(which is dependent on libvirt_type).'), ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(OPTS) return CONF.libvirt_uri or self.per_type_uris.get(CONF.libvirt_type, 'qemu:///system')

commit_message:
Retry on creating trove network

For pretty weird reason, first request to create a network to the neutron
fails with 500 without reasonable stack trace. Re-running request succeeds.
So we adding retries to the task which resolves metnioned issue.

commit_message:
Remove incorrect plugins configuration for docker image.

These plugins are not working with docker image because of docker architecture, 
this kind of metrics are collected by cadvisor plugin.

commit_message:
Use Python3 in client side to run Python2 functional tests

This change makes Python2 functional tests use Python 3 client side
to avoid "InterpreterNotFound: python2.7" error with tox in focal.
Server side processes are still launched on Python 2.7.

Change-Id: Ie2ac2b6c05d54e5a7798447ce7c120c2422140e4

subject: Add warning log when restarting docker container
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-01-30 06:46:32.000000000', 'files': ['storlets/gateway/gateways/docker/runtime.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/storlets/commit/1f67a8c42cbccc5919cbb1c307b1169045e48b4d', 'message': 'Add warning log when restarting docker container

When a storlet application or its dependencies are updated, we first
try restarting storlet daemon, but if it fails then we restart the
whole container, which might cause ungraceful shutdown of the other
storlet daemon in the same container.

This change adds a warning log so that operators can understand how
many times such stop failure have happened in the deployment.

Change-Id: I2843bf1118505a2e32e1f80e7329ed73de1cd62d
'}]
commit_message:
Add warning log when restarting docker container

When a storlet application or its dependencies are updated, we first
try restarting storlet daemon, but if it fails then we restart the
whole container, which might cause ungraceful shutdown of the other
storlet daemon in the same container.

This change adds a warning log so that operators can understand how
many times such stop failure have happened in the deployment.

Change-Id: I2843bf1118505a2e32e1f80e7329ed73de1cd62d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/storlets refs/changes/26/773226/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self.logger.debug('Failed to check Storlet daemon status, ' 'restart Docker container') self.logger.debug('Going to start storlet daemon!')

commit_message:
backup dependents failure

Incremental backup created fails, its parent_id will record the id of the parent backup, but num_dependent_backup is not increased by 1, resulting in has_dependent_backups being false, but the deletion of the parent backup will fails. This patch adds 1 to the num_dependent_backup of the parent backup when the backup creation fails.

Change-Id: I97afdc561b346abb87c3801aaab4b9f3e7492d6d
Closes-Bug: #1907542
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/40/767440/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'metadata': metadata or {}, 'num_dependent_backups': 0, } if backup.parent_id: parent_backup = objects.Backup.get_by_id(ctxt, backup.parent_id) parent_backup.num_dependent_backups += 1 parent_backup.save()

commit_message:
Nova kubernetes changes

* Changed interface to listen to 0.0.0.0
* Allows the user to point at a cluster for the following services that
  isn't defined by the Ansible hostvars:
	* RabbitMQ
	* MemcacheD
	* Neutron
	* Keystone

Change-Id: Iadbdd3aa43f9ba91ec820220fb8828e69161c579
Co-authored-by: Ryan Hallisey <rhallise@redhat.com>
Partially-implements: blueprint api-interface-bind-address-override

commit_message:
Spec - Zero-downtime upgrade in Kolla

An outline of supporting zero-downtime upgrade by Kolla internal.

Change-Id: I3316f57d722a02088bc1564ea8abf6bfcc613c4e
Co-Authored-By: Hieu LE <hieulq@vn.fujitsu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/98/409598/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================ Zero downtime upgrade with Kolla ================================ OpenStack services rolling upgrade and zero-downtime upgrade implementation status is varied between services and it is still in active development. Currently, Kolla only implements upgrade mechanism from services. As deployment tool, Kolla should support fully upgrade, capture and bring avalability of service to higher degree. Problem description =================== Firstly, in order to upgrade OpenStack services, Kolla ultilizes these mechanism via calling service CLI and total downtime is equal or larger (than) service downtime. Secondly, in Kolla (especially Kolla-Ansible), every services are put beind HAProxy. So even in best case that some services support rolling upgrade (in which at some point we need to put some nodes down), but there is still a chance HAProxy does not realize that current node is down when upgrading, so user sees a downtime here, even other nodes are still running. Thirdly, as the deployment tool, users need Kolla fully supporting the rolling-upgrade features from OpenStack services and toward the zero-downtime goals. Currently, because OpenStack services are in development for rolling-upgrade (with minimal downtime), so the total downtime of the whole OpenStack system deployed by Kolla is a gap we need to solve. Proposed change ================ 1. Adding buffer layer to HAProxy, this layer serves as HTTP(s) requests buffering, storing requests in memory. Buffering can be enabled in upgrading progress and disable afterthat. Users will meet some delay while sending requests to OpenStack services but no downtime happen. 2. Adding buffer layer for Message Queue. 3. Upgrading process can consume lots of time in case of very big database. So this buffer layer solution is the first step to solve the problem of upgrading downtime. We need to integrate another mechanism such as blue-green upgrade [3] with this buffer layer for completely eliminate the downtime. Dependencies ------------ Following solutions is just in first stage of PoC, but any suggestion is welcome. - OpenResty [1] with Intermission [2] as HTTP buffer layer. Proposed architecture --------------------- +----------------------------+ | Client | +-------------+--------------+ | | +------------ v--------------+ | | | +------------------------+ | | | OpenResty/Intermission | | | +------------------------+ | | | | Buffering | | | +-------------+--------------+ | | +-------------v--------------+ | HAProxy | +-------------+--------------+ | | +-------------v--------------+ | Backends | +----------------------------+ Implementation ============== Primary Assignee(s) ------------------- Duong Ha-Quang (duonghq) Hieu LE (hieulq) Work Items ---------- 1. Containerize buffering layer 2. Implement buffer deployment and control mechanism in Ansible 3. Implement buffer deployment and control mechanism in Kubernetes Documentation Impact ==================== TBA Demonstration (PoC) =================== OpenResty/Intermission is tested buffering while upgrade Neutron in AIO setup. Demonstration clip is uploaded at [4]. References ========== - [1] - https://openresty.org/en/ - [2] - https://github.com/basecamp/intermission - [3] - http://martinfowler.com/bliki/BlueGreenDeployment.html - [4] - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ss37ZzXW2Xc

commit_message:
Allow Kolla to deploy neutron with ovn

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kolla/+spec/neutron-ovn

Change-Id: I113bb725d8662c47e1ac2672e50ac899dbc16d1f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/28/576728/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ====================================== Allow Kolla to deploy neutron with ovn ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kolla/+spec/neutron-ovn Kolla currently only supports traditional neutron deployment. This spec suggests to allow Kolla to deploy neutron with ovn [1] , and make the neutron_ovn configurable. Problem description =================== In the traditional neutron deployment environment, neutron provides virtual L2 and L3 function, and also security groups implemented by iptables. OVN (Open Virtual Network) is a subproject of OVS (Open vSwitch) to support virtual network abstraction, OVN complements the existing capabilities of Open vSwitch to add native support for virtual network abstractions, such as virtual L2 and L3 overlays and security groups. Deployment of neutron with ovn can improve network performance and will make network more distributed. ovn has been adopted by other deployment framework like TripleO [3] . Use cases --------- 1. Deploy Kolla and enable neutron_ovn in the configuration file (change the value of the parameter ``enable_neutron_ovn`` to ``true`` in ``/etc/kolla/globals.yml``) Proposed change =============== Exposing the neutron_ovn option ------------------------------- Define new configuration parameter ``enable_neutron_ovn`` in Kolla configuration file ``/etc/kolla/globals.yml`` to indicate neutron ovn is used in Kolla. Add neutron_ovn related playbook -------------------------------- Add new neutron ovn related playbook to kolla-ansible project. No need to worry about the neutron_ovn docker image since it already exists. Security Impact --------------- There is no security impact introduced. Performance Impact ------------------ There is performance improvement for networking. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Rocky Work Items ---------- 1. Expose neutron_ovn option in Kolla configuration file 2. Write neutron_ovn related playbook 3. Update the docs Testing ======= The existing gate checks will be used to ensure neutron ovn successful deployment. Documentation Impact ==================== The reference page ``Networking in Kolla`` [2] should be updated. The page will document how to deploy neutron with ovn. References ========== [1] http://www.openvswitch.org//support/dist-docs/ovn-architecture.7.html [2] https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/reference/networking-guide.html [3] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/e7cd03d2f0fcd8e3069246ced94f1a83869b8bea

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-24 23:29:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/9fb6d020063fc2cd17945ddfcd80a8ef01df64ed', 'message': 'Horizon Frontend - (for kolla-kubernetes)

This patch allows for an haproxy based frontend container to be

Two new variables are defined:
 * horizon_versions: an array of versions that are part of the
   system. Defaults to ["1"]
 * horizon_version_default: new browser sessions coming in are

will continue to work on version 1 (say, Mitaka based), and all new
connections will go to version 2 (say, Newton based), allowing
version 1 to be gracefully drained and eventually deleted:
  horizon_versions: ["1", "2"]

commit_message:
Horizon Frontend - (for kolla-kubernetes)

Horizon is a web application that is distributed between the web
server, and the web browser. If the web server is upgraded while
the application is still running on the web browser, unusual issues
can creep up.

This patch allows for an haproxy based frontend container to be
created that, through kolla config options, allows multiple horizon
backends to be defined, browsers to be temporarily bound to the
versions they initially landed on, and new horizons introduced for
testing and promotion to default.

Two new variables are defined:
 * horizon_versions: an array of versions that are part of the
   system. Defaults to ["1"]
 * horizon_version_default: new browser sessions coming in are
   defaulted to this version. Defaults to "1"

So, for example, with the following config, older existing sessions
will continue to work on version 1 (say, Mitaka based), and all new
connections will go to version 2 (say, Newton based), allowing
version 1 to be gracefully drained and eventually deleted:
  horizon_versions: ["1", "2"]
  horizon_version_default: "2"

It is intended to be used along with corresponding logic in Kolla-Kubernetes.

Change-Id: I2dcd0fc224a959cc36cb7fd2a2adc99be280b7ff

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE!: PoC of ansible override

We can't merge this until we deal with license issues. This strategy
plugin will allow to include custom tasks into ansible playbook without
changing kolla code.

To include file after any task with Aodh in name, put this into
globals.yml

ansible_override:
    include_after:
        task: "Aodh"
        file: "/home/ubuntu/test.yml"

Change-Id: If5f6a6479ebf5b94a2a55dc40d55c2e00f20a5e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/51/395851/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ansible.playbook.task_include import TaskInclude from ansible.playbook.block import Block from ansible.plugins.strategy.linear import StrategyModule as LinearStrategy def inject_tasks(blocks, parent=None): for idx, block in enumerate(blocks): if isinstance(block, Block): inject_tasks(block.block, parent=block) else: if not block._variable_manager: continue override = block._variable_manager.get_vars(block._loader, task=block)['ansible_override'] if "include_after" in override and override['include_after']['task'] in block.name: include = override['include_after']['file'] include_task = TaskInclude.load( {'include': include}, block=parent, variable_manager=block._variable_manager, role=block._role) parent.block.insert(idx + 1, include_task) class StrategyModule(LinearStrategy): def run(self, iterator, play_context): inject_tasks(iterator._blocks) return super(StrategyModule, self).run(iterator, play_context)

commit_message:
Update docs of Instantiate CNF for scale and heal

Usage guides for how to deploy ETSI NFV-SOL containerized VNF is added
in user docs.
This patch updates the VNFD for CNF scale and heal operation, and
updates result of show command.

Change-Id: I7da0b7a25d8225006c3bcaf9d49f935756259921
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/76/781176/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ETSI NFV-SOL CNF (Containerized VNF) Deployment.. note:: `metadata.name` in this file should be the same as `properties.name` of the corresponding VDU in the deployment flavor definition file. For the example in this procedure, `metadata.name` is same as `topology_template.node_templates.VDU1.properties.name` in the helloworld3_df_simple.yaml file. VDU1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.Vdu.Compute properties: name: curry-probe-test001 description: kubernetes controller resource as VDU vdu_profile: min_number_of_instances: 1 max_number_of_instances: 3 policies: - scaling_aspects: type: tosca.policies.nfv.ScalingAspects properties: aspects: vdu1_aspect: name: vdu1_aspect description: vdu1 scaling aspect max_scale_level: 2 step_deltas: - delta_1 - vdu1_initial_delta: type: tosca.policies.nfv.VduInitialDelta properties: initial_delta: number_of_instances: 1 targets: [ VDU1 ] - vdu1_scaling_aspect_deltas: type: tosca.policies.nfv.VduScalingAspectDeltas properties: aspect: vdu1_aspect deltas: delta_1: number_of_instances: 1 targets: [ VDU1 ] - instantiation_levels: type: tosca.policies.nfv.InstantiationLevels properties: levels: instantiation_level_1: description: Smallest size scale_info: vdu1_aspect: scale_level: 0 instantiation_level_2: description: Largest size scale_info: vdu1_aspect: scale_level: 2 default_level: instantiation_level_1 - vdu1_instantiation_levels: type: tosca.policies.nfv.VduInstantiationLevels properties: levels: instantiation_level_1: number_of_instances: 1 instantiation_level_2: number_of_instances: 3 targets: [ VDU1 ] .. note:: `VDU1.properties.name` should be same as `metadata.name` that defined in Kubernetes object file. Therefore, `VDU1.properties.name` should be followed naming rules of Kubernetes resource name. About detail of naming rules, please refer to Kubernetes document [#fifth]_. | | "scaleStatus": [ | | | { | | | "aspectId": "vdu1_aspect", | | | "scaleLevel": 0 | | | } | | | ], | | | "vnfcResourceInfo": [ | | | { | | | "id": "686b356f-8096-4e24-99e5-3c81d36341be", | | | "vduId": "VDU1", | | | "computeResource": { | | | "vimConnectionId": null, | | | "resourceId": "curry-probe-test001-766bdd79bf-wgc7m", | | | "vimLevelResourceType": "Deployment" | | | }, | | | "storageResourceIds": [] | | | } | | | ], | | | "interfaceInfo": {}, |.. [#fifth] https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/working-with-objects/names/#dns-subdomain-names

added_lines: #!/usr/local/bin/dumb-init /bin/bash set -o errexit # Wait for the log socket if [[ ! "${!SKIP_LOG_SETUP[@]}" && -e /var/lib/kolla/heka ]]; then while [[ ! -S /var/lib/kolla/heka/log ]]; do sleep 1 done fi # Processing /var/lib/kolla/config_files/config.json as root. This is necessary # to permit certain files to be controlled by the root user which should # not be writable by the dropped-privileged user, especially /run_command sudo -E kolla_set_configs CMD=$(cat /run_command) ARGS="" if [[ ! "${!KOLLA_SKIP_EXTEND_START[@]}" ]]; then # Run additional commands if present . kolla_extend_start fi echo "Running command: '${CMD}${ARGS:+ $ARGS}'" exec ${CMD} ${ARGS}

Do not use mirror host for Ceph Luminous

the required contents.

for collecting and processing metrics.

commit_message:
New test, extends test_subport_connectivity

Related-Bug: #1869244

Adding new test, test_subport_connectivity_soft_reboot
The test is checking trunks and ports are recreated during server
reboots, especialy in ovs_dpdk ports,
Since test flow is variant of test_subport_connectivity
Two methods added and used in the tests:
_create_servers_with_trunk_port
_check_servers_remote_connectivity

Change-Id: Ia5fbe680bb904680f52e0e15056d629717a643af

commit_message:
[WIP] POC of buffering layer for Neutron

Intermission can be used as buffer layer for OpenStack service.

Demonstrated in [1]

[1] https://www.openstack.org/videos/boston-2017/openstack-cluster-zero-downtime-upgrade-with-kolla

Change-Id: I7a8d2fc64b037196ce3e52e7dc4f26bdb844a89b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/90/485090/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --Copyright 2012-2014 37signals / Taylor Weibley local sleep_time = tonumber(ngx.var.intermission_interval) local max_time = tonumber(ngx.var.intermission_max_time) local pausedreqs = ngx.shared.pausedreqs local health_check_path = ngx.var.intermission_health_check_path local privileged_user_agent = ngx.var.intermission_privileged_user_agent local app_name local enabled_key local id_key local paused_key --Check for app_name and 'scope' keys with it. if ngx.var.app_name == nil then enabled_key = "enabled" id_key = "id" paused_key = "paused" else app_name = tostring(ngx.var.app_name) enabled_key = "enabled_" .. app_name id_key = "id" .. app_name paused_key = "paused_" .. app_name end if pausedreqs:get(enabled_key) then --Pass healthchecks no matter what. if ngx.var.uri == health_check_path or ngx.var.uri == '/up' then ngx.log(ngx.DEBUG, 'Passing through health check request.') return end --Pass special user agent no matter what. (Pingdom perhaps?) if ngx.var.http_user_agent and ngx.var.http_user_agent ~= '' then if string.match(ngx.var.http_user_agent, privileged_user_agent) then ngx.log(ngx.DEBUG, 'Passing through privileged user agent request.') return end end --Auto inc counter for each paused request if pausedreqs:get(id_key) == nil then pausedreqs:set(id_key, 0) end --Increment the id local id = pausedreqs:incr(id_key, 1) ngx.log(ngx.DEBUG, 'Pause id:' .. id) --Add to our queue of paused requests local succ, err = pausedreqs:add(paused_key .. id, 1) if succ then ngx.log(ngx.DEBUG, 'Pause id added ' .. tostring(succ)) local wait_time = 0; repeat --First check the global state then check if the request ahead of us is still here if pausedreqs:get(enabled_key) == nil and pausedreqs:get(paused_key .. id - 1) == nil then ngx.log(ngx.DEBUG, "Unpause id: " .. id .. " after " .. wait_time .. " seconds") pausedreqs:delete(paused_key .. id) return else ngx.sleep(sleep_time) wait_time = wait_time + sleep_time --Warning will be *very* noisy with a small sleep_time ngx.log(ngx.DEBUG, 'Pause id:' .. id .. ' waiting for ' .. wait_time .. ' seconds total') end until wait_time > max_time else ngx.log(ngx.err, 'Failed to add pause id.') end else --Self explanatory return end

commit_message:
Fix Docker registry port error in image-building.rst

The default port of Docker registry is 5000. But the 5000 port is also
the port of keystone-api. To avoid conflict, use 4000 port as Docker
registry port.

Change-Id: I3885cdbb3d4e68db2d34e479b2e974286036fdd7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/78/415678/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: kolla-build --registry 172.22.2.81:4000 --push

commit_message:
Add UEFI deploy file in ironic pxe container

Currently, ironic which deployed by kolla-ansible just support pxe
method to deploy OS, add support for UEFI deploy.

The UEFI support guide is in "PXE UEFI setup" section:
https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-pxe.html

Use 'project' instead of 'tenant'

While switching to openstackclient we use project instead
of tenant.

commit_message:
Kube OVS DB to listen on tcp:port and neutron-ovs-agent to use script

This PS adds tcp socket to ovsdb process to listen to and it also changes
neutron-openvswitch-agent start command. It will start via script which  now
accepts orchestration specific parameters.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I0c5e51fbce7776ba38eb1cca4b040017b0d69351

commit_message:
Add external ceph support for cinder and glance

Modify the conditional strategy for cinder and glance regarding ceph:
use cinder_volume_driver and glance_volume_driver instead of
enable_ceph.

Introduced some config values into globals.yml and passwords.yml to be
able to use the ceph driver without deploying a ceph cluster.

This strategy could be used in other versions.

WARNING: before merging into "stable", please test the non-regression
in the "enable_ceph=yes" situation (deploying a ceph cluster). It
should be compatible but has not been tested.

Co-Authored-By: Mathias Ewald <mewald@evoila.de>
Change-Id: If05eefcf1c91e4d564ec32d12d144f47564162d6
Implements: spec external-ceph
Signed-off-by: Sebastien Fuchs <sebastien@emmene-moi.fr>

commit_message:
Optimize bluestore deployment in kolla

The following optimizations were made to the bluestore deployment:

1. Change osd partition-related naming rules to easily obtain relevant
disk information
2. In find_disks.py, separate the disk information of ceph and other
components, and optimize disk results for filestore and bluestore,
discard disk information that is not relevant.
3. Direct use of disk partition variables, no additional judgment is
required to determine the disk type.
4. Supports three combinations of partition labels to initialize osd.
5. Solved the problem of block partition computing weight error.
6. Modify the type id of the osd partition to avoid container startup
failure caused by ceph automount.

Change-Id: Ic2cd282eb81368b7361a8012544e0b240102e3f5
Closes-bug: #1776888

subject: Support multipath disk for bluestore in kolla
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-09-05 08:09:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/08fbba1ace4f01657655a88a1602741a0dd3c046', 'message': "Deploy bluestore directly with partition name in kolla

1.In the bluestore initialization code, the device name and the
partition sequence are used to splicing the partition name, but
this causes a certain code redundancy and doesn't support other
devices, such as bcache devices. This patch solves this problem
and uses the partition name directly.
2.Optimized the return information of find_disks.py, only returns
valid disk information, does not return null values.
3.When osd_initial_weight is auto, kolla will calculate the weight
according to the size of the disk, so when using bluestore, it need
to calculate the weight according to the size of the block.

Change-Id: I5b544a966edf5f0814cc14fd964d04c4687045e1

1. Support for bluestore osd deployment on multipath disks.
2. Because the symbolic link of the multipath disk uses the format
of 'typecode.partuuid', in order to maintain consistency, the symbolic
link of the regular disk changes from partlabel to partuuid.
3. There are many types of disk naming suffixes that are 'p+number',
such as the default naming of multipath disks, bcache disks, but the
script currently only supports loop devices, this patch fixes this
problem.
4. Optimized the return information of find_disks.py, only returns
valid disk information, does not return null values.
5. Kolla supports calculating the weight of osd according to the size
of the disk. The current script uses the osd data partition(100M) when
calculating the weight of the bluestore osd. The block partition
should be used. This patch fixes this problem.

Closes-bug: #1741489

Change-Id: I5b544a966edf5f0814cc14fd964d04c4687045e1

commit_message:
Support multipath disk for bluestore in kolla

1. Support for bluestore osd deployment on multipath disks.
2. Because the symbolic link of the multipath disk uses the format
of 'typecode.partuuid', in order to maintain consistency, the symbolic
link of the regular disk changes from partlabel to partuuid.
3. There are many types of disk naming suffixes that are 'p+number',
such as the default naming of multipath disks, bcache disks, but the
script currently only supports loop devices, this patch fixes this
problem.
4. Optimized the return information of find_disks.py, only returns
valid disk information, does not return null values.
5. Kolla supports calculating the weight of osd according to the size
of the disk. The current script uses the osd data partition(100M) when
calculating the weight of the bluestore osd. The block partition
should be used. This patch fixes this problem.

Closes-bug: #1741489

Change-Id: I5b544a966edf5f0814cc14fd964d04c4687045e1

commit_message:
Corrects missing packages from Xen

Two additional packages are necessary for xen to properly install
on the compute nodes. These packages are python2 and needed only
in the centos binary deployments. Xen is only compatible with that
version of openstack.

Change-Id: Id6ddb5688184b18e6fab11f3252a9083bffda5aa
Closes-bug: #1837767

commit_message:
Upgrade Haproxy to version 1.8.x

Haproxy in centos 7 repos version is only 1.5.18 [1].
It's quite outdated. Kolla should upgrade Haproxy
package to 1.8.x version for new features.

Use centos software collections repo. Haproxy
version up to 1.8.17. [2]

[1] http://mirror.centos.org/centos/7/os/x86_64/Packages/haproxy-1.5.18-8.el7.x86_64.rpm
[2] https://www.softwarecollections.org/en/scls/rhscl/rh-haproxy18/

Change-Id: Iaba10969c8bdea80b690848a9aa2f955e47c8b1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/78/671178/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {% block haproxy_install %} # Haproxy 1.8.17 {% if install_type == 'binary' %} {% if base_distro in ['centos', 'oraclelinux', 'rhel'] %} {% set haproxy_packages = [ 'rh-haproxy18' ] %} {% elif base_distro in ['debian', 'ubuntu'] %} {% set haproxy_packages = [ 'haproxy' ] %} {% endif %} {% if base_distro in ['centos', 'rhel'] %} RUN ln -s /opt/rh/rh-haproxy18/root/usr/sbin/haproxy /usr/sbin/haproxy {% endif %} # Haproxy 1.8.20 {% elif install_type == 'source' %} {% if base_distro in ['centos', 'oraclelinux', 'rhel'] %} {% set haproxy_packages = [ 'gcc-c++', 'openssl-devel', 'pcre2', 'pcre2-devel', 'make' ] %} {% elif base_distro in ['debian', 'ubuntu'] %} {% set haproxy_packages = [ 'gcc-c++', 'libc6-dev', 'liblua5.3-dev', 'libpcre2-dev', 'libssl-dev', 'make', 'zlib1g-dev' ] %} {% endif %} {{ macros.install_packages(haproxy_packages | customizable("packages")) }} {% block haproxy_version %} ENV HAPROXY_VERSION 1.8.20 ENV HAPROXY_URL https://www.haproxy.org/download/1.8/src/haproxy-1.8.20.tar.gz ENV HAPROXY_SHA256 3228f78d5fe1dfbaccf41bf387e36b08eeef6e16330053cafde5fa303e262b16 {% endblock %} RUN curl -sSL -o /tmp/haproxy.tar.gz "${HAPROXY_URL}" \ && echo "$HAPROXY_SHA256 /tmp/haproxy.tar.gz" | sha256sum -c \ && mkdir -p /usr/src/haproxy \ && tar -xzf /tmp/haproxy.tar.gz -C /usr/src/haproxy --strip-components=1 \ && rm /tmp/haproxy.tar.gz \ \ && makeOpts=' \ TARGET=linux2628 \ USE_GETADDRINFO=1 \ USE_OPENSSL=1 \ USE_PCRE2=1 USE_PCRE2_JIT=1 \ USE_ZLIB=1 \ ARCH=native \ CPU=x86_64 \ ' \ && nproc="$(nproc)" \ && eval "make -C /usr/src/haproxy -j '$nproc' all $makeOpts" \ && eval "make -C /usr/src/haproxy install-bin $makeOpts" \ \ && mkdir -p /usr/local/etc/haproxy \ && cp -R /usr/src/haproxy/examples/errorfiles /usr/local/etc/haproxy/errors \ && rm -rf /usr/src/haproxy \ && ln -s /usr/local/sbin/haproxy /usr/sbin/haproxy {% endif %}{% endblock %}

commit_message:
split templates to work around configparser bug

Move the percent character to the template from the string to allow
setting either % or %% as needed to work around the bug linked below.
This requires each service 'family' to have two versions of it's config
file.

Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1872553

Change-Id: I68f276224c51d5682d77123eae697767fadf9b19
Signed-off-by: Matthew Thode <mthode@mthode.org>
(cherry picked from commit 3e151d97adbff78be1b146938374a0dced5970e9)

commit_message:
Publish weekly

To better utilise caches during the working week, we decided
to publish only weekly (as opposed to daily).
This is due to DockerHub-imposed limits.

Change-Id: Ib4710dae09e991c0ad21c44a64b2617e0fd4fdc6

commit_message:
Adding support of subnet_dns_publish_fixed_ip extension in ml2 plugin

The subnet-dns-publish-fixed-ip extension adds a new attribute to the definition of the subnet resource. When set to true it will allow publishing DNS records for fixed IPs from that subnet independent of the restrictions described in the [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-dns-int-ext-serv.html

Change-Id: I095564cec0f5804e4d0ea9b5201ed40b9d9be603

commit_message:
Extend timeout for RPM verification

For systems with many packages deployed or heavy loaded environments
rpm verification takes the way more time then 5 minutes ending up in
corrupted database of the rpm packages. So we set limit to 1 hour
and extending amount of retries to wait for result to match the async
timeout

Change-Id: I30d29630214914bea99fc7fd66afa3218705d733
Closes-Bug: #1921292

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-03-23 16:34:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8b060648f8ba76b63992645578fd6a04f16361cf', 'message': '[OVN] Make delete_router_port() less error prone

resilient to NotFound errors. Apart from the L3 plugin, this method is

commit_message:
[OVN] Make delete_router_port() less error prone

This commit makes the delete_router_port() method from OVNClient more
resilient to NotFound errors. Apart from the L3 plugin, this method is
also invoked by the maintenance task to fix stale/not-up-to-date objects
in the OVN database, and since the maintenance task runs every 5 minutes
only it could happen that some objects fetched by delete_router_port()
are gone by the moment that method is invoked.

Change-Id: I0d78278797beb2af42ec38462e2b2edc8e2a4ae6
Closes-Bug: #1920968
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
rpc: Rename 'instance_type' client argument

Rename the 'instance_type' argument of the 'prep_resize' and
'resize_instance' client methods. This wasn't done in change
Id2e467c43d5b7c6bafd5dbbbf8d5d06be6dc7e30 to keep that change as compact
as possible.

Change-Id: I78fa69f8f7a6affe95d719802d490713ec31f62c
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/25/782825/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
DNM: Rename 'instance_type' parameter

Instance types are dead. Long live flavors.

There are *loads* more references to 'instance_type' here. We don't
touch a single one of these. Those will be done in a follow-up like
change I264d6df1809d7283415e69a66a9153829b8df537.

Change-Id: Id792473a3bfdc2b88ab5c5319277344d37fae69f
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Process subordinate releases packages map

For principal - subordinate plugin type relations where the
principal Python payload imports code from packages managed by a
subordinate, upgrades can be problematic.

This change will allow a subordinate charm that have opted into the
feature to inform its principal about all implemented release -
packages combinations ahead of time. With this information in place
the principal can do the upgrade in one operation without risk of
charm relation RPC type processing at a critical moment.

Also sync c-h.

Closes-Bug: #1806111
Change-Id: I95567d5d047eb64842436e671b74a633e6f509f4
